resources.string:
The Network Survey app requires a few permissions to work. Denying these permissions will result in the app not functioning properly. 

1. Find Nearby Devices: This app does not connect to nearby devices. Instead, it needs this permission to perform a Bluetooth scan for survey. 

2. Make and Manage Phone Calls: This app does not make or manage phone calls. Instead, it needs this permission to get access to the current cellular connection type (e.g. LTE vs UMTS). 

3. Access this Device's Location: The location permission is needed to access Wi-Fi details, Cellular details, GNSS details, and also to write geo-relevant log files. 

4. Access Photos, Media, and Files on Your Device: This permission allows the log file to be written. 

5. Notifications: This permission allows NS to add a notification so you know when a survey is running in the background.

The Network Survey app requires a few permissions for Call Detail Record (CDR) logging to work. Denying these permissions will result CDR logging not working. 

1. Make and Manage Phone Calls: This app does not make or manage phone calls. Instead, it needs this permission to get cellular details to write to the CDR log file. 

2. Access this Device's Location: The location permission is needed to access Cellular details that are used to write to the CDR file. 

3. Access Photos, Media, and Files on Your Device: This permission allows the log file to be written. 

4. Notifications: This permission allows NS to add a notification so you know when a survey is running in the background. 

There is a known bug where this permission dialog keep showing, but the permission request dialog does not show up after hitting OK. You can work around this by uninstalling and reinstalling the app and approving all the permissions the first time, or opening the Android settings and manually approving the required permissions.

In addition to the required permissions that were listed in a different dialog, CDR logging has an optional permission. \n\n1. Read Phone Number: This is needed to get this device\'s phone number for writing it to a CDR log file. You can deny this permission and CDR logging will still work except your phone number won\'t be logged.

The upload feature allows you to share collected cellular and Wi-Fi survey data with third-party databases.

How This Feature Works:
• When started, survey records collected by the app are written to an internal database. You can then decide whether to upload the stored records to the selected destinations.
• When stopped, no survey data is written to the internal database, and no survey data is uploaded to a third-party database.

Where Your Data Goes:
Your survey data will be uploaded to one or both of the following services, depending on your selections:
• OpenCelliD - A global open-source cell tower database.
• BeaconDB - A crowdsourced geolocation database.

What Data Is Uploaded:
• Device Location (Latitude, Longitude, Altitude, Accuracy, Speed)
• Cellular Information (MCC, MNC, TAC/LAC, Cell ID, Signal Strength, Timing Advance, PCI, ARFCN, etc.)
• Wi-Fi Information (SSID, BSSID, Frequency, Channel, Signal Strength, Encryption Type)
• Timestamp of Collection

When new records are written to the database
Cellular and Wi-Fi Survey data is written to the database only if it contains all the required information, AND if the location of the device has changed by at least 35 meters since the last record was written. This is to prevent an excessive amount of survey data from being uploaded to the servers for the same location.

Data is anonymized and used to improve cellular and Wi-Fi coverage mapping, as well as enhance the BeaconDB geolocation service.

For more details, visit the Network Survey User Manual.

What is a CDR? A CDR is a Call Detail Record that has an event for specific interaction a phone has with the cellular network. For example, a phone call, sms messages, and certain tower changes. The Network Survey app has a CDR File Logging feature that allows for logging CDR events to a CSV file. There are several possible use cases for recording a CDR; for example, one might be to have a record of what your phone is doing, and what towers it is communicating with. \n\nWorthy of note, the regular version of Network Survey does not log SMS events in the CDR, nor does it support logging the "other" phone number associated with a phone call. Logging SMS events requires the full SMS permission, and Google Play won\'t approve publishing Network Survey to the Play Store if it requests the SMS permission. If you are interested in a CDR logger that supports SMS events and logging the "other" phone number for call events, check out the information in the Network Survey User Manual: https://networksurvey.app/manual#cdr

Need help understanding the File Logging and MQTT sections? Here's a quick guide:

 File Logging Control:
 This section is all about saving data locally to your phone. When you toggle one of the options to 'On', the app will start logging that data type to a file in GeoPackage and/or CSV format (depending on the configured setting), which you can find on your device. Remember:
 
 - Toggle Cellular, Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, GNSS, and/or CDR under File Logging Control to save this data locally.
 - Logging is completely optional and does not affect MQTT Streaming.
 
 MQTT Connection:
 MQTT streaming lets you send your data in real-time to a remote server. No local storage is needed for this:
 
 - First, configure the broker connection settings.
 - Ensure the switch is on to activate streaming.
 - MQTT Streaming works independently of File Logging. You don't need to turn on File Logging to stream data.
 
 Use File Logging for local storage and MQTT Streaming for remote transmission. They both capture the same data, but work independently, so you have full control over how you handle your data.
The Find Nearby Devices permission is needed to perform a Bluetooth scan for survey. If this permission is denied then Bluetooth survey will not work.

The location permission is needed to access Wi-Fi details, Cellular details, GNSS details, and also to write geo-relevant log files.\n\nDenying the location permission will result in pretty much all of the features of this app not working.

Network Survey collects location data to enable starting Cellular, Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, and GNSS survey at boot, even when the app is closed or not in use. 

Without the background location permission, this app will not be able to start surveying Cellular, Wi-Fi, or GNSS at boot. If you don't want to start surveying when the phone boots then you don't need to enable this permission.

Enable the background location permission in the Android settings for this app by selecting Allow all the time on the next page.
The Find Nearby Devices Permission is required for Bluetooth Survey
The Bluetooth Connect permission is not required for BT survey, but it does allow for getting the device name
The Camera Permission is required for scanning QR codes

Start scanning to collect cellular and Wi-Fi survey data for upload to 3rd party DBs. This operates independently of file logging and MQTT streaming, allowing you to start and stop data collection specifically for upload. Click the question mark icon for more details.

Uploading your survey records will share location data with third-party services. Contributing to these crowdsourced databases helps improve coverage maps and geolocation accuracy. Your participation is entirely voluntary—the choice to share your data is yours and yours alone.
You have to enter a valid access token in preferences

MCC (Mobile Country Code): Unique country identifier for mobile networks.

 MNC (Mobile Network Code): Unique network identifier within the country. Together the MCC and MNC represent a specific service provider (e.g. T-Mobile).

 LAC (Location Area Code): Identifier for a group of cell towers that is used for paging.

 CID (Cell Identity): Identifier for a specific cell tower. Together the MCC, MNC, LAC and CID uniquely identifies a specific GSM cell panel from all others in the world.

 ARFCN (Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number): Number representing the GSM carrier frequency.

 BSIC (Base Station Identity Code): A physical layer cell identifier that helps a mobile device differentiate two cells during cell selection/reselection that are using the same frequency.

 RSSI (Received Signal Strength Indicator): Received power of the downlink signal in dBm as received by the mobile device.

MCC (Mobile Country Code): Unique country identifier for mobile networks.

 MNC (Mobile Network Code): Unique network identifier within the country. Together the MCC and MNC represent a specific service provider (e.g. T-Mobile).

 LAC (Location Area Code): Identifier for a group of cell towers that is used for paging.

 CID (Cell Identity): Identifier for a specific cell tower. Together the MCC, MNC, LAC, and CID uniquely identifies a specific UMTS cell panel from all others in the world.

 UARFCN (UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number): Number representing UMTS carrier frequency.

 PSC (Primary Scrambling Code): A physical layer cell identifier that helps a mobile device differentiate two cells that are using the same frequency.

 RSSI (Received Signal Strength Indicator): Received power of the downlink signal in dBm as received by the mobile device.

 RSCP (Reference Signal Code Power): Power of the reference signal in dBm as received by the mobile device.

MCC (Mobile Country Code): Unique country identifier for mobile networks.

 MNC (Mobile Network Code): Unique network identifier within the country. Together the MCC and MNC represent a specific service provider (e.g. T-Mobile).

 TAC (Tracking Area Code): Identifier for a group of cell towers that is used for paging.

 CID (Cell Identity): Identifier for a specific cell tower. Together the MCC, MNC, and CID uniquely identifies a specific LTE cell panel from all others in the world.

 eNB ID (eNodeB Identifier): The cell tower identifier, which will contain one or more cell panels. This is the first 20 bits of the CID.

 Sector ID: Identifies a sector (aka panel) within a cell tower. This is the last 8 bits of the CID.

 EARFCN (E-UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number): Number representing LTE carrier frequency.

 Band: That band number representing the frequency range the EARFCN falls in.

 PCI (Physical Cell ID): A physical layer cell identifier that helps a mobile device differentiate two cells during cell selection/reselection that are using the same frequency. Valid range 0-503. The numbers in parenthesis represent the Primary Sync Sequence (PSS) and Secondary Sync Sequence (SSS).

 Bandwidth: Width of the signal.

 TA (Timing Advance): The timing offset a mobile device uses to keep its transmissions in sync with the tower. Represents RF distance from the tower, which can be loosely translated to physical distance. Larger numbers indicate the device is further away from the tower.

 CQI (Channel Quality Indicator): Used by the UE to notify the serving cell (eNodeB) about the quality of the downlink channel. Valid range 0-15 with 15 being the best.

 RSRP (Reference Signal Received Power): Power of the reference signal in dBm as received by the mobile device. Valid range -44 to -140.

 RSRQ (Reference Signal Received Quality): Measures the quality of the received reference signal. Valid range -3 to -19.5 with -3 being the best.

 SNR (Signal to Noise Ratio): The Reference Signal Signal-to-Noise Ratio measured in dB. Full Range: -20 dB to +30 dB, with 30 being the best. Common range is 5 to 15 ish.

MCC (Mobile Country Code): Unique country identifier for mobile networks.

 MNC (Mobile Network Code): Unique network identifier within the country. Together the MCC and MNC represent a specific service provider (e.g. T-Mobile).

 TAC (Tracking Area Code): Identifier for a group of cell towers that is used for paging.

 CID (Cell Identity): Identifier for a specific cell tower. Together the MCC, MNC, and CID uniquely identifies a specific NR cell panel from all others in the world.

 NARFCN (New radio Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number): Number representing NR carrier frequency.

 PCI (Physical Cell ID): A physical layer cell identifier that helps a mobile device differentiate two cells during cell selection/reselection that are using the same frequency. Valid range 0-1007. The numbers in parenthesis represent the Primary Sync Sequence (PSS) and Secondary Sync Sequence (SSS).

 TA (Timing Advance): The timing offset a mobile device uses to keep its transmissions in sync with the tower. Represents RF distance from the tower, which can be loosely translated to physical distance. Larger numbers indicate the device is further away from the tower.

 SS_RSRP (Secondary Synchronization Reference Signal Received Power): Power of the reference signal in dBm as received by the mobile device. Valid range -31 to -156.

 SS_RSRQ (Secondary Synchronization Reference Signal Received Quality): Measures the quality of the received reference signal. Valid range 20 to -43 with 20 being the best.

The override network type is for market branding or visualization purposes only. It cannot be treated as the actual network type the device is camped on.\n\nIn other words, service providers want the user to think they are on a better network than they actually are such as showing 5G in the top bar when it is really a 4G network.

Here you can connect to a Network Survey server. Once connected, all future survey results will be streamed to the server. 

Steps for Connecting: 

1. Enter in the following information: 
 a. The Server IP Address or Hostname 
 b. The Server Port Number (Default: 2621) 
 c. A name that is used to identify this device on the server 

2. Click the connect toggle switch
The Network Survey Service runs when the app needs to do work in the background such as write to the log file or stream data out over active connection
The Connection Service handles managing the connection to a remote server to stream Network Survey data
Streaming records to an MQTT Broker
Pause Wi-Fi network scan UI updates
Android 9 throttles Wi-Fi scans to 2 per minute. Upgrade Android if possible.
Android 10+ throttles Wi-Fi scans. To disable throttling: System -> Advanced -> Developer options -> WiFi scan throttling to off.
To enable Developer Options: Settings -> About Phone -> Tap Build Number 7 times.
If true, when the phone boots an attempt will be made to connect to the MDM configured MQTT broker
The port number to use when connecting to the MQTT broker (e.g. 8883)
True to use SSL/TLS for the MQTT connection, false to use a plaintext connection
The name this device should use to represent itself to the MQTT broker
The username to use when authenticating to the MQTT broker
The password to use when authenticating to the MQTT broker

The prefix to use on the standard MQTT topics used by Network Survey. For example, setting the value to "my/custom/topic/" will result in LTE messages being set on "my/custom/topic/lte_message". The default value is empty.
True to stream cellular data, false otherwise
True to stream Wi-Fi data, false otherwise
True to stream Bluetooth data, false otherwise
True to stream GNSS data, false otherwise
True to stream Device Status messages over MQTT, false otherwise
True to start cellular logging automatically, false otherwise
True to start Wi-Fi logging automatically, false otherwise
True to start Bluetooth logging automatically, false otherwise
True to start GNSS logging automatically, false otherwise
True to start CDR logging automatically, false otherwise

True to ignore showing the throttling warning snackbar message on the Wi-Fi UI, false to allow the snackbar message to work as normal. The snackbar message tells the user if Wi-Fi throttling is enabled, and gives them a link to turn off throttling in developer options. If developer options are disabled via MDM, then set this to true so the user is not asked to open developer options.
Network Survey is controlled via MDM, but now some of the MDM settings can be overridden
Network Survey is controlled via MDM
The maximum file size (in MB) before starting a new survey log file. The default value is 5 MB.
Specifies what type of file to log the survey results to. The options are 0, 1, or 2. 0 is for CSV, 1 is for GeoPackage, and 2 is for both CSV and GeoPackage.
Cellular logging will be started upon app opening or when the phone is turned on
Cellular logging will only start when manually enabled
Wi-Fi logging will be started upon app opening or when the phone is turned on
Wi-Fi logging will only start when manually enabled
Bluetooth logging will be started upon app opening or when the phone is turned on
Bluetooth logging will only start when manually enabled
GNSS logging will be started upon app opening or when the phone is turned on
GNSS logging will only start when manually enabled
CDR logging will be started upon app opening or when the phone is turned on
CDR logging will only start when manually enabled
The rate at which Cellular towers will be scanned for in seconds. Smaller values will decrease battery life.
The rate at which Wi-Fi networks will be scanned for in seconds. Smaller values will decrease battery life.
The rate at which Bluetooth devices will be scanned for in seconds. Smaller values will decrease battery life.
The rate at which GNSS satellites will be scanned for in seconds. Smaller values will decrease battery life.
The rate at which Device Status messages will be generated in seconds.

Specifies what provider to use for getting the device's location. The devices location is added to log files and MQTT messages.

 FUSED: Combines inputs from GNSS and NETWORK location providers to provide the most battery efficient location fix, but can be less accurate.

 GNSS: Determines location using GNSS satellites (e.g. GPS). This uses more battery than NETWORK based, but is typically more accurate.

 NETWORK: Determines location based on nearby cell towers and Wi-Fi access points.

 ALL: Uses all the location providers and adds each location to the device status message, which results in multiple locations written in the device status message. Useful if you want to compare the locations for analysis purpose; or the best possible location fix.
Specifies what provider to use for getting the device\'s location. The options are 0, 1, 2, or 3. 0 is for FUSED, 1 is for GNSS, 2 is for NETWORK, and 3 is for ALL.
Allow other apps to Start NS
True to allow other apps to start Network Survey via an Intent
Other apps can start Network Survey
Other apps will be blocked from starting Network Survey
Serving cell coverage will be displayed on the map
Serving cell coverage won\'t be displayed on the map
True to allow users to upload survey records to 3rd Party databases such as OpenCelliD and BeaconDB, false to prevent it
The MQTT connection will be started when the phone is booted (Note that a valid MQTT broker must be configured in the connection UI)
The MQTT connection will only be started manually
Logs location fix details to a file
Click here to view the privacy policy
Location (GPS/GNSS) is disabled. It is required for tying cellular survey records to a location and to also get GNSS details. \n\nDo you want to enable it now?

Network Survey is not receiving raw GNSS measurements from the phone, which are required for generating the GNSS GeoPackage/CSV files, or streaming GNSS records over MQTT. For more information and a list of devices that support raw GNSS, consult Android\'s Raw GNSS Measurements guide.
Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) satellites not available
Satellite-based Augmentation System (SBAS) satellites not available

The device GNSS time of:

%1$s

…is more than %2$d days different from your system clock. This can be caused by the GPS week rollover issue - ask your device manufacturer for details. See https://bit.ly/gps-week-rollover for more info.
GNSS provider or Location is disabled, no updates until it\'s enabled
Device does not support tracking of GNSS Navigation Messages
GNSS Navigation Messages are successfully being tracked
GNSS provider or Location is disabled, no updates until it\'s enabled
Device does not support tracking of GNSS Measurements
GNSS Measurements are successfully being tracked
Upload successful. Thanks for your contribution!
Partially uploaded mean that some data has been successfully sent before upload has been aborted. This may be caused by your request or by an error which has been encountered.
Upload failed due to unknown reason. Please check if you have the latest version of the app. If you encounter this problem for a long time, please let me know.
User with the access token entered in app preferences cannot be found. Please check if entered access token is correct.
Server refused the data send by the app. Please check if you have the latest version of the app. If you encounter this problem for a long time, please let me know.
There is no data to upload. Please collect some measurements before uploading.
Application encountered an error while deleting measurements from your device. Please restart your device and check again. If you still encounter this problem, please let me know.

The server could not be reached due to network related error which may be caused by missing, too slow or unstable Internet connection. Please check if you have latest application version and try again. If you encounter this problem for a long time, please let me know.

The server returned internal error which may mean that it is overloaded, temporarily unavailable or down for maintenance. Please try again later. If you encounter this problem for a long time, please let me know.
Upload cancelled due to denied internet permission.
The daily usage limit for the app has been exceeded. Please try again tomorrow.
Cannot upload due to no Internet connection.
An error occurred, will retry later
External upload has been disabled via MDM
An error occurred when trying to start saving records for upload
Started scanning and saving records for upload
Stopped scanning and saving records for upload
This action will permanently delete all survey records stored for upload. \n\nAre you sure you want to proceed?
All upload data has been deleted
Upload dialog will be skipped and the settings below will be used
The config dialog will be shown before each upload
